docs.lead_paragraph: The new law strikes out a clause that made it possible for a woman to obtain an abortion legally if her own life is in danger.

docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists for the first time have grown human heart valves using stem cells from the fluid that cushions babies in the womb, offering an approach that may be used to repair defective hearts.

headline.main: Stem Cell Experiment Yields Heart Valves
headline.print_headline: Stem Cell Experiment Yields Heart Valves

docs.snippet: Scientists for the first time have grown human heart valves using stem cells from the fluid that cushions babies in the womb, offering an approach that may be used to repair defective hearts.

headline.main: Readers Respond to ‘How to Fight Poverty: 8 Programs That Work’

docs.lead_paragraph: Babies born at just 22 weeks or less should not be routinely resuscitated, according to new British medical guidelines for doctors and parents. The Nuffield Council on Bioethics, an independent ethics body that published the guidelines, added that those born between 22 and 23 weeks should not normally receive intensive care unless parents request it and doctors agree. The council, which looks at ethical questions raised by advances in medical care, said that it was ''extremely rare'' for such babies to survive and that they should not go ''through the stress and pain of invasive treatment.'' The guidelines oppose the euthanasia of extremely premature babies ''no matter how serious their condition.'' Dr. Tony Calland, head of the medical ethics committee of the British Medical Association, expressed concern over the ''stringent cut-off points for treatment'' and said the association believed ''each case should be considered on its merits and its own context.''

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Report Suggests No Care For Early Babies

docs.abstract: Independent British ethics body publishes guidelines on treatment of babies born at 22 weeks or less; guidelines oppose euthanasia of extremely premature babies; Dr Tony Calland, head of medical ethics committee of British Medical Association, says each case should be considered on its own merits (S)
